an3.156-162:4.3: The addicted practice, the scorching practice, and the middle practice.
an3.156-162:4.5: It’s when someone has this doctrine and view:
an3.156-162:4.7: so they fall into indulgence in sensual pleasures.
an3.156-162:4.8: This is called the addicted practice.
an3.156-162:5.2: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when asked. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on purpose for them, or an invitation for a meal.
an3.156-162:5.3: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breast-feeding, or who has a man in her home; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or liquor or wine, and drink no beer.
an3.156-162:5.4: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to
an3.156-162:5.6: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to
an3.156-162:5.8: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to
an3.156-162:5.10: and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
an3.156-162:6.1: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
an3.156-162:7.1: They wear robes of hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings. They tear out hair and beard, committed to this practice. They constantly stand, refusing seats. They squat, committed to persisting in the squatting position. They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed. They’re committed to the practice of immersion in water three times a day, including the evening.
an3.156-162:7.2: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of torturing and tormenting the body.
an3.156-162:7.3: This is called the scorching practice.
an3.156-162:8.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
an3.156-162:8.3: They meditate by observing an aspect of feelings …
an3.156-162:8.4: They meditate by observing an aspect of the mind …
an3.156-162:8.5: They meditate by observing an aspect of principles, keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
an3.156-162:8.6: This is called the middle practice.
an3.156-162:8.7: These are the three practices. (1)
an3.156-162:9.3: The addicted practice, the blistering practice, the middle practice.
an3.156-162:9.5: This is called the tough practice.
an3.156-162:10.1: And what is the scorching practice? …
an3.156-162:10.2: This is called the scorching practice.
an3.156-162:11.2: It’s when a mendicant generates enthusiasm, tries, makes an effort, exerts the mind, and endeavors so that bad, unwholesome qualities don’t arise.
an3.156-162:11.3: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that bad, unwholesome qualities that have arisen are given up.
an3.156-162:11.4: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that wholesome qualities arise.
an3.156-162:11.5: They generate enthusiasm, try, make an effort, exert the mind, and endeavor so that wholesome qualities that have arisen remain, are not lost, but increase, mature, and are completed by development.
an3.156-162:12.1: They develop the basis for psychic power that has samādhi due to enthusiasm, and active endeavor. They develop the basis for psychic power that has samādhi due to energy, and active endeavor.
an3.156-162:12.2: They develop the basis for psychic power that has samādhi due to higher mind, and active endeavor.
an3.156-162:12.3: They develop the basis for psychic power that has samādhi due to inquiry, and active endeavor.
an3.156-162:13.1: They develop the faculty of faith …
an3.156-162:14.1: They develop the power of faith …
an3.156-162:15.1: They develop the awakening-factor of mindfulness …
an3.156-162:16.9: This is called the middle practice.
an3.156-162:16.10: These are the three practices. (7)
